content.rendered:
An Introduction to the ESI Scheme

Employees State Insurance Corporation (ESIC) is a government-operated organization working to manage the Employees’ State Insurance Scheme. The said Scheme of the government of India provides medical and financial assistance to the employees. In case the employee is unable to work due to sickness, employment injuries, or maternity, ESI Scheme comes into force.

Critical Components of the Scheme

The Employees’ State Insurance Act of 1948 governs the ESI Scheme. Following is a breakdown of the critical components of the Scheme:

Scope of Coverage: The Scheme covers employees who are subscribed or enrolled in the program. It may be mandatory for employers to register their employees for the Scheme, or it could be an opt-in option for employees to participate voluntarily.

Protection against Employment Injury: The Scheme provides coverage to employees who sustain injuries or disabilities directly related to their work. This may include accidents, occupational diseases, or other work-related health conditions.

Sickness Benefits: In case of non-work-related sickness or medical conditions, the Scheme provides financial assistance to employees to help them cope with the loss of income during their illness.

Maternity Benefits: The Scheme supports female employees during pregnancy and childbirth. Maternity benefits can include paid leave during the maternity period to help them manage their financial needs.

Medical Care and Other Benefits: The Scheme provides access to medical care and other benefits to covered employees. Medical expenses related to injuries, sickness, and maternity may be covered under the Scheme to ensure that employees can receive necessary treatments without significant financial burden.

Replacing Loss of Salary: One of the critical objectives of the Scheme is to replace a portion of the employee’s lost salary or income during periods of disability, sickness, or maternity leave. This financial assistance helps individuals and their families maintain a basic living standard during these challenging times.

The primary goal of the ESI scheme is to provide a safety net for employees and their families, ensuring their well-being and financial stability during times of need.

 

History of Employees’ State Insurance Corporation

Prime Minister Pandit Jawahar Lal Nehru inaugurated the Scheme in Kanpur on 24th February 1952. The venue was the Brijender Swarup Park. The Scheme was simultaneously launched in Delhi as well, and the initial coverage for both centers was 1,20,000 employees. Our first prime Minister was the first honorary insured person of the Scheme, and the declaration form bearing his signature is a prized possession of the Employees’ State Insurance Corporation.

 

How Does the ESIC Works?

a.) Where is it applicable?

The ESI scheme applies to entities or establishments that employ ten or more employees. The Scheme covers various sectors and industries, including shops, hotels, restaurants, cinemas, road motor transport establishments, newspaper establishments, and private educational and medical institutions. The number of employees required to subscribe to the ESI scheme can vary between states. Each state government has the authority to determine the minimum threshold for coverage. For instance, in some states, the threshold may be ten or more employees, while in others, it may be twenty or more employees. Therefore, it is essential to refer to the specific rules and guidelines set by the state government where the entity is located to determine the precise applicability criteria.

Additionally, the ESI scheme provides medical care, cash benefits, and various other facilities to covered employees and their dependents. The employer and the employee contribute to the Scheme, and the funds are managed by the Employees’ State Insurance Corporation (ESIC), a statutory body under the Ministry of Labour and Employment, Government of India.

b.) Wage Limit

Employees working for factories or establishments with ten or more employees earning a monthly salary of up to Rs. 21,000 are entitled to health benefits under the ESI Act in India.

Regarding exemptions, individuals with a daily average wage of Rs. 176/- or below are exempted from contributing to the ESI scheme from their wages. Only the employer’s contribution is paid for these employees in such cases. This exemption relieves lower-wage employees from contributing a portion of their salary towards the ESI scheme while still providing them access to health benefits. It is important to note that the specific thresholds and exemptions may vary between states and can be subject to updates or changes by the relevant authorities.

 

ESIC Registration process

Step 1: Log in to ESIC Portal

  • An employer requires getting himself registered on the ESIC portal.
  • An employer can register by clicking the ‘Sign Up’ button on the ESIC portal under the ‘Employer Login option on the home screen.
  • The employers must fill in the details after clicking the ‘Sign up’ button and submitting the form.

Step 2: Confirmation Mail

After submitting the form for sign-up to the portal, the employer will obtain a confirmation mail sent to the registered mail ID & mobile number entered at the time of sign-up. For registering as an employer & employee under the ESIC scheme, the email will contain the username & password details.

Step 3: Employer Registration Form-1

  • Next, along with the username and password received in the mail, log in to the ESIC portal. This will pass on to the page having the option of ‘Tab – New Employer Registration.’ Click It.
  • Next, select the ‘Type of Unit’ from the drop-down list and click the ‘Submit’ button. The ‘Employer Registration – Form 1’ will come out & the employer requires filling in the details.
  • The Employer Registration Form-1 concedes details about the employer’s unit, details of the employer, and employees. He must click the ‘Submit’ button once; the employer fills out the complete form.

Step 4: Payment for Registration

The ‘Payment of Advance Contribution’ page will open after submission of the Employer Registration Form-1, where the employer requires filling the amount to be paid & select the payment mode. The employer will need to pay the advance contribution for 6 months.

Step 5: Registration Letter

  • The system-generated Registration Letter (C-11) is sent to the employer on the successful payment of the six months advance contribution, containing a 17-digit Registration Number by the ESIC department.
  • The Registration Letter (C-11) is a valid proof of employer registration.

 

 Conclusion

The  ESIC in India plays a crucial role in providing social security benefits to insured workers across the country. The Scheme offers a range of benefits, including cash benefits, medical care, maternity benefits, disablement benefits, and more.

The ESIC ensures that insured persons have access to quality medical facilities and treatment through its network of ESIC Hospitals and hospital annexes. The ESI Card or e-Pehchan Card serves as a unique identification for insured individuals and enables them to avail of medical benefits and other entitlements.

The ESIC Portal and digital initiatives have made it easier for insured persons to access and manage their benefits, including filing claims and checking their contribution history. It also provides convenient access to various services and information related to the ESIC Health Scheme.

The ESIC operates under the Ministry of Labour and Employment, Government of India, and is a legal entity. It collects insurance contributions from employers based on the rate of contribution determined by the Central Government. The funds collected are used to provide healthcare benefits and other social security measures to insured workers and their dependents.

The coverage of employees under the ESIC Scheme extends to various sectors, including industrial workers, factory workers, newspaper establishments, and more. Female workers also benefit from specific provisions such as maternity benefits. The ESIC ensures that employees are protected against occupational diseases and provides disability benefits when needed.

The ESIC’s network of offices, including the ESIC Head Office, regional/sub-regional offices, and divisional offices, ensures efficient administration and service delivery. The Association of India and other stakeholders play a vital role in promoting and safeguarding the rights of insured persons.

At Last

The ESIC in India has made significant strides in providing social security and medical benefits to the working population. The ESIC ensures the well-being of injured workers and their dependents, contributing to a healthier and more secure workforce.

It is advisable to consult and seek legal advice to understand the registration of ESIC in your region. For online legal advice, please contact Legal251 on toll-free no.- (+91) 77728-77729 or download the Legal251 mobile app now.
